results.title: Tale of one city
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Department of Housing, Environment and Community Development, Peter Johnson and Zoran Janjic
results.brief_description: This film uses animation in a light-hearted manner to show some of the problems of living in a modern city, the need for more careful urban planning to help alleviate these problems, and the way in which pressure groups have an important influence on the town planners.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Department of Housing, Environment and Community Development, Peter Johnson and Zoran Janjic

results.title: Tale of a TV mouse
results.brief_description: The story of a puppet mouse named Lucille, whose entire life revolves around the television. Shows how it affects her life and what finally happens to convince her to break the TV habit. Presents the problems of habitual TV viewing and provides positive alternatives for children who watch a lot of TV.

results.title: Tal Farlow
results.brief_description: Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 1950s, was not recommenced until the 1980s. Unfortunately he died before completing it. It contains vertical white scratches as well as geometric white scratches on black. It was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

results.title: Taking their place
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Jack S. Allan and Loch Townsend
results.brief_description: Government film about the rehabilitation and re-employment of the physically handicapped in the “normal workforce”. Follows Noel Simpson, a paraplegic, through this process.

results.title: Taking our bodies back
results.brief_description: This film documents a growing movement of women to regain control of their bodies, and it shows women becoming aware of their rights in dealing with the medical industry. The film explores critical areas of the women’s health movement, including self-help and self-examination; giving birth at home; breast cancer and abortion.

results.title: Taking it in stride: positive approaches to stress management
results.brief_description: Life has a way of getting more and more hectic as time goes by. For many of us, it is a major accomplishment to simply get through the day. This film offers hope by going beyond an analysis of the ‘Stress Response’ and its link to disease. It focuses on solutions, skills for coping with stress.

results.title: Taking chances
results.creator_credit: Janina Craig Screen Services, Community Services Victoria, Australian Bicentennial Authority, Film Victoria, Ann Darrouzet and David Taft
results.brief_description: Discusses recreation and leisure options for intellectually disabled poeple and the benefits to organisers, participants and parents. Profiles intellectually disabled people participating in an aquabuddy program, competitive darts, basketball, radio broadcasting and gardening. Emphasises a focus on ability rather than disability.

results.title: Taking care of yourself: breast self-examination
results.creator_credit: Instant Replay Productions, Westmead Hospital and New South Wales Cancer Council
results.brief_description: Most women take care of their bodies, however very few of them check their breasts as often as they should. This program explains the importance of regular breast self-examination, and provides a step-by-step guide for carrying out effective examinations. It also provides guidelines on what to look out for when carrying out breast self-examination.

results.title: Taking care of your pets
results.brief_description: An appeal to all animal lovers to assist with the humane work of caring for our sick and injured animal population. Illustrates the medical attention provided at the Dogs’ Home and Hospital; the work of ambulances treating animals injured by modern high-speed traffic; the work of the dog catchers collecting stray animals from the streets and the subsequent care of these at the Dogs’ Home.
